author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘Don’t Kill My Child. Kill Me Instead.’
description: The world has largely abandoned Sudan, but this woman risked everything to stand up to evil.
content: Side by side with the worst of humanity, you regularly encounter the best. And so it was that while covering murder, rape and starvation in Sudan, I was awed by a heroic refugee, Naima Adam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Robert Gebeloff and Meridith Kohut
title: The American Drug Mules Smuggling Fentanyl Into the U.S.
description: Mexican drug cartels are turning thousands of Americans into fentanyl smugglers, sending an army of couriers who can easily cross between both countries.
content: The teenager practiced driving from his apartment in San Diego down to Tijuana and back, on the orders of the criminals he was working for in Mexico. He rehearsed how he would respond to questions from U.S. border officers. He tracked when the drug-sniffing dogs took a break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: More Than 400 Roads Closed in North Carolina After Damage From Helene
description: The closures, including on two interstates, left motorists scrambling for options.
content: In addition to the power outages caused by Helene that have crippled the western part of North Carolina, swaths of roadways in the region were largely impassable on Saturday, prompting alerts from transportation officials that warned drivers to stay out of their vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: A Family’s Desperate Flight Through Helene’s Rising Floodwaters
description: When a family in Shore Acres, Fla., feared the water would rise to their roof, they made a decision to swim out to safety.
content: Ariel Lopez and his wife, Tiffany, thought Helene would be like Hurricane Idalia, which brought about four inches of storm surge into their home in Shore Acres, a flood-prone neighborhood of St. Petersburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Barrett and Hank Sanders
title: ‘I’m in Trouble Now’: North Carolinians Face Dangerous Floods From Helene
description: A nurse in Asheville, N.C., found herself chest deep in water in her S.U.V. before she was rescued by a police officer.
content: As the Swannanoa River swelled and overflowed from heavy rains brought by Helene, residents of Asheville, N.C., described moments of fear and anxiety amid dangerous flooding in their region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft, Elisabeth Parker, Valerie Boey Ramsey and Patricia Mazzei
title: As Florida Storms Worsen, Some in Tampa Bay Wonder: Is Living There Worth It?
description: Residents of the booming region are confronting a new reality: Even when storms make landfall far away, their impact is being felt.
content: Living near the gleaming expanse of Tampa Bay in Florida used to require a certain calculus: Fear the Big One, a powerful hurricane that would tear into the densely populated region and drown people and property. But also rest assured that most Gulf of Mexico storms are near-misses — one has not directly hit Tampa since 1921 — and keep enjoying life on the coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Antônio Delfim Netto, Brazilian Economic Czar, Dies at 96
description: He was credited for the high-growth economy during the early years of Brazil’s long military dictatorship. But critics said his policies brought only short-lived gains.
content: Antônio Delfim Netto, the Brazilian finance minister who was credited for the high-growth economy known as the “Brazilian miracle” during the early years of the country’s 21-year military dictatorship, but then excoriated for the hyperinflation and recession that followed, died on Aug. 12 in São Paulo. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,198
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 29, 2024
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad, Vivian Yee and Jacob Roubai
title: Stark Reality After Israel’s Latest Assault: Even Beirut Isn’t Safe
description: “Nobody has any idea what to do,” said one of the many residents who fled the Dahiya, an area near the Lebanese capital where Hezbollah holds sway, amid overnight Israeli airstrikes.
content: The streets of Beirut, Lebanon, were eerily empty on Saturday morning. Most stores were shuttered, and few cars passed along the usually bustling streets. Drones buzzed overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Newsom Vetoes Bill Requiring Cars to Warn Speeding Drivers
description: The legislation would have made California the first state in the nation to require intelligent speed assistance technology in vehicles.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Saturday vetoed California legislation that would have mandated that all new cars in the state have a system that alerts drivers when they exceed the speed limit by more than 10 miles per hour.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: F.D.A. Approves the First New Drug to Treat Schizophrenia in Decades
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 27, 2024
content: “It’s not even a needle in a haystack, it’s kind of like a needle in a stack of needles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan and Audra D. S. Burch
title: In Atlanta, Flooding From Helene Forced Some Residents to Wade to Safety
description: In the Buckhead neighborhood, waters from a swollen creek rushed into low-lying apartments.
content: When Helene marched north through Georgia on Thursday and Friday, it caused flash flooding and power outages across the state, including an already soaked Atlanta. The city reported 21 water rescues in one highly affected area, and about 100,000 households overall were without electricity on Friday, with flash flood emergency alerts for the region in effect. Mayor Andre Dickens declared a state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Protesters Mourn Nasrallah’s Death Around the World
description: Protesters gathered on Saturday not only in Lebanon, but also in Iran, in the West Bank and elsewhere to mourn his assassination.
content: Protests took place on Saturday in multiple countries mourning the assassination of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant organization Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Hezbollah’s Victims Express Relief at Its Disarray
description: Amid widespread condemnation of Israel’s massive strikes, Syrian communities persecuted by Hezbollah forces voiced cautious, and sometimes exuberant, celebration.
content: Even as most of the Middle East is overtaken by outrage at weeks of destructive Israeli strikes against Hezbollah and its leaders, some communities are celebrating the disarray of the powerful militia that persecuted them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: John Oliver Is Still Working Through the Rage
description: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.
content: Nobody is doing late-night comedy quite like John Oliver. Oliver first became known to U.S. audiences as the senior British correspondent for “The Daily Show,” bringing a keen outsider’s eye and observational humor to American political dysfunction. But since 2014, he has been hosting his own show, “Last Week Tonight,” on HBO, winning 30 Emmys and the respect of a devoted audience for his very funny, meticulously researched deep dives into subjects that few would consider obvious comedic fodder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow, 103, Dies; His Tenure Leading UNESCO Was Stormy
description: He was the first Black African to head a major international organization, but complaints about his administration led the U.S. and Britain to pull out of it.
content: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow, a Senegalese civil servant and politician who became the first Black African to head a major international organization when he was elected director general of UNESCO — but whose contested tenure there led the United States and Britain to pull out — died on Tuesday in Dakar, Senegal. He was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Co-op Banned My E-Bike, Which I Need. Can They Do That?
description: The co-op has to protect the safety of everyone in the building. But it also must comply with its own bylaws.
content: Q: My New York City co-op building has voted to ban my electronic bike, which I use to get my child to and from medical appointments. I have filed for a request for an accommodation under the Fair Housing Act, with letters from my son’s doctor and from mine. The co-op board won’t reverse the ban, nor did it offer an alternative. They asked that future communications be made by my lawyer. This ban would add at least an hour each day to my commute, and I cannot afford a car. Do I have options? Can the building just ignore my request?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Eakin
title: Why Jackson Pollock Owed Everything to Claude Monet
description: A new biography of the French Impressionist argues that Monet himself owed everything to the three most important women in his life.
content: In the years before World War II, as modern art began to reach a broad international audience, a powerful origin story emerged about the 20th-century avant-garde. In this telling, the epochal revolt initiated by Picasso and Matisse had been spurred by a few trailblazing forebears — Paul Cézanne, Vincent van Gogh, Paul Gauguin and Georges Seurat, mainly. Notably left out was Claude Monet (1840-1926), whose shimmering Impressionist paintings had made the unstable act of seeing an end in itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Julian E. Barnes
title: Strike on Hezbollah Deepens Disconnect Between Biden and Netanyahu
description: Israeli officials gave their American counterparts no advance warning of the strike that killed Hassan Nasrallah, the longtime leader of Hezbollah, according to U.S. officials. But Mr. Biden said the killing was “a measure of justice” for victims of Hezbollah terrorism.
content: No one inside the White House was crying for Hassan Nasrallah on Saturday. But the Israeli strike that killed Mr. Nasrallah, the longtime leader of Hezbollah, once again deepened tensions between President Biden’s administration and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Hamed Aleaziz and Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris, at the Border, Shows Democrats’ Hard-Line Evolution on Immigration
description: Vowing to carry on President Biden’s crackdown on asylum and to impose order on the southern border, the vice president demonstrated how much the politics of immigration have changed.
content: On her first trip to the southern border as the Democratic presidential nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered one of her party’s toughest speeches on immigration and border policy in a generation. Even as she did, she tried to paint former President Donald J. Trump as a feckless chaos agent without the ability to deliver the hard-line results he has promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Desi Lydic Wants to Be in Central Park, Listening to Chappell Roan
description: “I love getting out and about early in the day, getting some fresh air and sunlight and seeing the city,” the “Daily Show” host said of her morning ritual.
content: In one of her auditions for “The Daily Show,” the comedian and actress Desi Lydic did an impression that, as she put it, “was kind of going for that ex-lawyer, four-time beauty pageant winner and overqualified but leggy Fox News blowhard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Go Ahead, Gild That Lily
description: Andy Baraghani’s tahini apple tart sparkles. No, really: The sesame seeds and sugar on the crust give it real luster (and crunch).
content: I can’t resist a flourish. I’ve never once abided by that “remove one thing before you leave the house” rule — why would I take off something I paid money for and love? This shows up in my cooking as well: Rice always gets a shower of furikake, salads always get croutons, chili always gets a thatched blanket of shredded Cheddar (and scallions and sour cream and fried onions and hot sauce). Some might call it an inability to leave well enough alone. I call it living a little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Launches Mission to Bring Back Starliner Astronauts
description: Two astronauts — one American, one Russian — are headed to the International Space Station with two empty seats for crewmates who are already in orbit.
content: Lifted by a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, two astronauts left Earth on Saturday afternoon, headed to the International Space Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: A Slippery Devil Finally Gets His Moment at MoMA
description: The German artist Thomas Schütte expects blowback when a retrospective of his work opens. Maybe he even enjoys that prospect.
content: On a recent morning in a tidy workshop a half-hour from his home in Düsseldorf, Thomas Schütte, one of Europe’s most celebrated artists, was face to face with a devil. It was deep blue, stout as a gnome, with phallic horns, grasping arms and gaping eyeholes. Soon to be cast in bronze, the sculpture was up on a forklift so its maker could look it in the eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: At Least 104 Die as Monsoon Rains Inundate Nepal
description: Disasters in the small Himalayan nation have become more frequent as the effects of climate change intensify.
content: At least 104 people have died in Nepal, the authorities said, after three days of incessant monsoon rains unleashed flooding and landslides across the small Himalayan nation, which has been increasingly pummeled by the effects of climate change. In addition, at least 73 people have been injured, and 64 are still missing, the Nepal Police said. Most of the deaths were reported on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Boxerman
title: As Hezbollah Threat Loomed, Israel Built Up Its Spy Agencies
description: After the 2006 war with Hezbollah, Israel invested heavily to intercept the group’s communications and track its commanders in a shadowy war that ultimately led to the killing of the group’s leader.
content: In the immediate days after the deadly Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel, Israeli intelligence officials feared a pre-emptive strike was imminent from another longtime enemy, Hezbollah. They frantically prepared to stop it with plans to strike and kill Hassan Nasrallah, the powerful Hezbollah leader who the Israelis knew would be in a bunker in Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Michael Gold
title: Trump Criticizes Harris on the Border and the Economy in Michigan
description: Donald Trump used a pair of events to try to blame Kamala Harris for inflation and the migrant crisis, tapping into themes that helped him win Michigan in 2016.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Bayard
title: On ‘Downton Abbey,’ Maggie Smith Made an Icy Aristocrat Irresistible
description: The hit melodrama brought Smith the kind of fame she never wanted, but it is easy to understand why it happened.
content: In retrospect, Maggie Smith’s brilliant, high-wire career can be seen as a protest against celebrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Harris’s Historic Run Could Outpace Hollywood’s Oval Offices
description: Black and Asian American women have rarely, if at all, played the U.S. commander in chief in television and film. As Kamala Harris makes her presidential bid, Hollywood lags behind.
content: When Barack Obama was the Democratic nominee for president in 2008, James Earl Jones and Morgan Freeman had already portrayed commanders in chief on film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Rustic Respites
description: Margaret Seikel’s first Saturday puzzle is bound to hook you.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Margaret Seikel’s first Saturday puzzle for the New York Times Crossword and her ninth grid overall. Her notes indicate that its inspiration came from that glorious stack of entries from 14- to 21-Down and running with it. Thank goodness she did because they are marvelous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bill Lucy, Pioneering Labor and Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 90
description: He helped popularize “I Am a Man” as a demand for respect during the 1968 strike by Black sanitation workers in Memphis.
content: Bill Lucy, a trailblazing Black union leader who fought for civil rights in the American South and against apartheid in South Africa, and who pressured organized labor to address concerns about equal treatment for minority groups, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: How Being a Middle Child Shaped an Actress’s Style
description: Issa Rae prefers attire with “symmetry” and avoids flashy clothes. Plus: vintage Ralph Lauren and the sudden end of a cult brand.
content: “I just like things to be balanced, to be even on both sides,” Issa Rae said on a call this month. “Being a middle child, right in the middle of five, I always wanted things to be fair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: An Artist Whose Subjects Step Out of His Paintings
description: Adam Dressner, a lawyer turned portrait artist, began painting eccentric New Yorkers a few years ago. Many of them made an appearance at a recent exhibition.
content: As evening commuters streamed into Grand Central Terminal on Tuesday, they dashed past several large oil portraits displayed on easels in Vanderbilt Hall on the way to catch their trains. Had they ventured inside the space, they would have experienced the strange sensation of mingling in the crowd with the paintings’ subjects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Ahead of Debate, Walz Is Viewed More Favorably Than Vance in Midwest, Polls Find
description: Gov. Tim Walz is viewed more favorably than Senator JD Vance by likely voters in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, according to New York Times/Siena College polls.
content: In the contest between Minnesota dad energy and “Hillbilly Elegy” energy, Midwestern voters appear to have a clear preference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Most Important Question Kamala Harris Hasn’t Answered
description: What would a President Harris do about the war in Ukraine?
content: Not all the policy questions left unanswered by Kamala Harris’s studiously vague presidential campaign are created equal. It is not especially urgent, for instance, to know how Harris’s views of the ideal health care system have evolved since the great Medicare for All debates of 2020, given the strong likelihood that as president she would share power with a Republican Congress and any sweeping domestic policy initiatives would be stillborn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabino Iglesias
title: 4 New Horror Books Filled With Eldritch Terrors and Other Frights
description: Our columnist reviews September’s new horror releases.
content: Powerful. Brutal. Bursting at the seams with cosmic horror, ennui, violence and self-annihilation. There are many ways to describe Laird Barron’s latest collection, NOT A SPECK OF LIGHT: Stories (Bad Hand Books, 370 pp., paperback, $19.99), but superb works just fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democratic Senate Candidates Lead in Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin, Polls Find
description: Strong showings in new Times/Siena College polls leave a narrow path open for Democrats to keep hold of the chamber, but Republicans maintain an advantage with the map.
content: Democratic Senate candidates in the Upper Midwest states of Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin hold leads over their Republican competitors, keeping a narrow path open to maintaining Democratic control of Congress’s upper chamber next year, according to new New York Times/Siena College polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: The Heart-Healthy Diet Hardly Anyone Is Talking About
description: The DASH diet was shown to lower blood pressure decades ago, yet few people follow it. Here’s how to give it a try.
content: When Dr. Deepak Gupta discusses blood pressure management strategies with his patients, they often jump to say that they know they should cut down on salt, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Jentleson
title: Kamala Harris Said She Owns a Gun for a Very Strategic Reason
description: She has been doing an effective job of vice signaling from the left.
content: At the presidential debate and on the campaign trail, Kamala Harris has hardly sounded like the Marxist or the Communist that Donald Trump has accused her of being. She hasn’t even sounded particularly progressive. At various times, she has said that she backs fracking, taunted Mr. Trump for his weakness in the face of dictators and bragged about owning a gun — going so far as to tell Oprah Winfrey, “if someone breaks in my house, they’re getting shot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler and Riley Mellen
title: 2,000-Pound Bombs Likely Used in Attack That Killed Nasrallah, Video Shows
description: A Times analysis of video from the Israeli military shows that at least eight planes it said were used in the attack on Hassan Nasrallah were armed with bunker-buster bombs.
content: A video published by the Israeli military showed that planes it said were used in the attack that killed Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, on Friday night carried 2,000-pound bombs, according to munitions experts and a New York Times analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 476
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 29, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Amid Lebanon Strike, Defiant Netanyahu Declares Israel Is ‘Winning’
description: The Israeli prime minister castigated Israel’s critics and the United Nations itself during his visit to New York for the U.N. General Assembly.
content: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Candidate for North Carolina Governor Treated for Burns, Campaign Says
description: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican nominee for governor of North Carolina, was treated after attending a campaign event in Mount Airy, N.C.
content: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican nominee for governor in North Carolina, was being treated for burn injuries on Friday night after an incident at a campaign event hosted at a truck show in Mount Airy, N.C., according to his spokesman and his political consultant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Ina Garten Figured Out How to Let Go of the Shame
description: A memoir? How easy is that.
content: It’s unnerving to watch Ina Garten get weepy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Yes, You Can Swim in Louboutins
description: Christian Louboutin enlisted the French Olympic synchronized swimming team to introduce his new Miss Z stilettos at Paris Fashion Week.
content: Christian Louboutin made a splash at Paris Fashion Week on Friday night when he staged “Paris is Louboutining,” a synchronized swimming spectacle at the Piscine Molitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Power and Communication Outages Hamper Assessment of Landslides
description: With communication lines down in the mountains amid Helene, early reports were unclear about how many landslides had occurred and the extent of damage from the storm.
content: More than a foot of rain turned major roadways in cities in the southeastern United States like Asheville, N.C., and Atlanta into floodplains on Friday when already saturated soils were overwhelmed by the torrential bands of Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Wong
title: Your Friend Has More Money Than You Do. How Can Your Relationship Survive?
description: Financial disparities in friendships can create conflict where it shouldn’t exist. Here’s how two friends navigated a growing wealth gap.
content: Adult friendships aren’t easy to maintain. Busy schedules and competing demands interfere with making time for friends. And when money is involved, friendships can become even more complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Dish and DirecTV Near a Deal to Combine (Again)
description: The companies are in talks to create one of the largest pay-TV providers in the country. In 2002, the U.S. government blocked a similar deal.
content: Business has gotten only more difficult for Charlie Ergen, the founder of the satellite TV giant Dish, since the government blocked his bid to combine his company with DirecTV in 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Harris Leads in Race for Eastern Nebraska’s One Electoral Vote, Poll Finds
description: If Ms. Harris were to win the “blue wall” and lose the Sun Belt swing states, the single electoral vote in Greater Omaha could determine the winner of the presidential election.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris holds a lead over former President Donald J. Trump for the single Electoral College vote in eastern Nebraska, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College, a potentially critical prize if the overall presidential contest remains on a knife’s edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Laborer’s Death Brings to Light Italy’s Conflicted Relationship With Migrants
description: Italy, an aging country, badly needs migrant labor and immigration, but the government has admitted that the pathways for legal entry are rife with abuse.
content: When Satnam Singh, a migrant fruit picker from India, chopped his arm off in an accident in June as he worked in fields near Rome, his boss, instead of taking Mr. Singh to a hospital, dropped him off in front of his house with part of his arm in a fruit basket. Shortly afterward, Mr. Singh died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aryn Baker
title: A Decimated Hezbollah Is a Serious Blow to Iran
description: How Iran responds to the death of the Lebanese militia’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in an Israeli airstrike will affect the region, and beyond.
content: The death of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah in an airstrike has dramatically weakened a key Iranian deterrent against its archenemy, Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Molly Recommends Small Takes on Big Ideas, and a Novel of Sisterhood
description: James Richardson’s aphorisms; Nora Lange’s novel “Us Fools”
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: A Wisconsin City Welcomed New Refugees. Then the Angry Billboards Went Up.
description: Eau Claire had a plan. But opponents, mostly from rural areas, were convinced that the newcomers would destroy their Midwestern way of life.
content: The billboards featured a foreboding message. Taxpayer money, it said, was footing the bill for a nonprofit to traffic Somali refugees — and officials in Eau Claire, Wis., had been hiding the facts for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Three Things to Look for in Any Election Poll
description: A new poll comes out. How should you interpret it? Here are some rules of thumb.
content: Election polls are everywhere. In news articles, on social media and maybe even in your group chat, you’re probably seeing loads of numbers, some of which seem to contradict one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: How JD Vance Turns Taking Questions Into the Show
description: He uses showdowns with reporters to cast himself as a pugnacious, unscripted defender of Donald J. Trump.
content: It was a little over 20 minutes into Senator JD Vance’s appearance at a campaign rally on Monday in Charlotte, N.C., when the real show began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: One Senator’s Vision for Supreme Court Accountability
description: One senator’s vision for Supreme Court accountability.
content: Longtime readers of this newsletter will know that I am a strong advocate of Supreme Court reform. The court, as I’ve argued many times, exists within the constitutional system and not outside it. It does not have the sole power to interpret the Constitution, and it is subject to congressional regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Israel’s Military Issues More Evacuation Warnings in Southern Beirut
description: The military struck targets throughout the night that it said were tied to Hezbollah.
content: Israel’s military issued expanded, middle-of-the-night warnings to residents of Beirut’s southern suburbs to evacuate early Saturday, just hours after earlier orders were followed by a series of airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Helene Cooper
title: Can Hezbollah Recover From the Death of Its Most Commanding Leader?
description: Hassan Nasrallah’s killing raises questions about whether the group can strike back at Israel. But U.S. officials say it’s too soon to count the group out.
content: For more than three decades, he was the face and brain of Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Water Around Tennessee Dam Receding After Heavy Rain From Helene
description: The authorities were evacuating people downstream from the Nolichucky Dam, warning that a breach could cause deadly flooding.
content: The Nolichucky Dam in eastern Tennessee remained intact late Saturday morning after extreme rainfall from Helene caused waters in the area to rise to record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Mass Shooting in South Africa Leaves 17 Dead
description: Most of the victims were women killed in one homestead, according to the police, who have started a manhunt for the gunmen.
content: At least 17 people from a single family were killed when gunmen attacked two homesteads in South Africa early Saturday, the police said, adding to a rising number of mass shootings in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Can Lina Khan Hold On?
description: Ms. Khan’s term as the chair of the Federal Trade Commission ended Wednesday. In a wide-ranging interview, she discussed her aggressive approach to antitrust and its critics.
content: From Wall Street to Silicon Valley, everyone wants to know what’s next for Lina Khan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Quong
title: In a White Gated Community, the Only Black Couple Wind Up Dead
description: The protagonist of Rivers Solomon’s novel “Model Home” has tried to outrun childhood trauma, but their ghosts lure them right back.
content: In the first chapter of Rivers Solomon’s fourth book, “Model Home,” the narrator, Ezri, and their teenage daughter, Elijah, give in to insomnia and watch a true-crime show on TV: “We both find solace in the inevitability of broken girls.” Ezri has not always been so fatalistic: “Abuse of power surprises me every time,” they told their own mother at 13; “I guess I hope every time it will be different.” This immediate contrast of past and present introduces an underlying mystery: How did Ezri lose their “earnest heart”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Laura Donnelly, ‘Hills of California’ Star, Is Not Some Delicate Flower
description: But she did “burst into tears” reading Jez Butterworth’s rewrite of his new Broadway play, which left her with 10 days “to create an entirely new character.”
content: Most plays that transfer to New York from London arrive in close to their original form. There might be small changes to the text, to make particular lines comprehensible to American ears, but usually not much more than that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: What Shohei Ohtani and His Magnificent Season Mean for You
description: What we can learn from the greatest season in baseball history.
content: On Thursday, Sept. 19, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Shohei Ohtani became the first player to hit 50 home runs and steal 50 bases in a single season. During his barrier-breaking game against the Miami Marlins, Ohtani also batted six-for-six, hit three home runs and drove home 10. Commentators called it the greatest single game in the greatest single season in Major League Baseball’s 121-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Chris Cameron
title: Vance Appears at Event of Evangelical Leader Who Spoke of Harris’s ‘Witchcraft’
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio campaigned in Pennsylvania at an event organized by Lance Wallnau, who described Vice President Kamala Harris’s debate performance as “witchcraft.”
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio campaigned Saturday in Pennsylvania at an event organized by Lance Wallnau, a self-described prophet who has said that former President Donald J. Trump was chosen by God, defended the Jan. 6 attack and described Vice President Kamala Harris’s debate performance as “witchcraft.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Viewfinders Make Fall Foliage Pop for the Colorblind in Virginia
description: Specialized viewfinders installed across state parks let visitors with red-green colorblindness see more distinct colors.
content: Like so many other leaf-peeping enthusiasts, Tim Yates ventured out to Virginia’s Smith Mountain Lake State Park late this summer to see the early whispers of the fall foliage, which would soon give way to bright bursts of orange and red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Patient Exposed to Bat in Minnesota Dies From Rabies, Officials Say
description: The death, which was reported on Friday, is only the fifth fatal human rabies case in Minnesota since 1975, health officials said.
content: A patient who was exposed to a bat in western Minnesota this year died from rabies this week, becoming the fifth person since 1975 to die from the treatable disease in the state, health officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Wasson
title: Francis Ford Coppola’s ‘Megalopolis’ Is Exactly the Risk Hollywood Needs
description: Spending a personal fortune to fund a passion project isn’t folly. It’s the ultimate kind of cinematic courage.
content: By now you may have heard about how Francis Ford Coppola spent, some say foolishly, over $100 million of his own money to produce “Megalopolis,” his fable of a future utopia, four decades in the making, which finally landed in theaters this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Ben Hubbard
title: Hassan Nasrallah, Who Led Hezbollah for Decades, Killed at 64
description: In 32 years in charge of Hezbollah, Mr. Nasrallah built the Iranian-backed militia into an influential regional force and a potent adversary of Israel.
content: Hassan Nasrallah, who led the militant Hezbollah organization in Lebanon for more than three decades and built it into a domestic political force and potent regional military power with ballistic missiles that could threaten Tel Aviv, was killed on Friday in heavy Israeli airstrikes just south of Beirut. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: We Tried to Shop Our Way to Cheaper Car Insurance. It Didn’t Work.
description: The normally unstoppable force of two veteran money reporters hit the immovable object of wretched industry conditions. Living in Brooklyn didn’t help.
content: We were bound to fail. We just didn’t know it when we started our quest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: The True Costs of America’s Gun Obsession
description: It’s not just murders and mass shootings. Guns play a role in many of the country’s biggest problems.
content: No other country comes close to matching America’s levels of gun ownership. In fact, the United States has more firearms than people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Could We See a 270-268 Election? The Polls Are Tighter Than Ever.
description: The latest Times/Siena polls show Harris slightly ahead in Michigan and Wisconsin, with a healthy lead in Nebraska’s Second District.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Newfoundland and Labrador’s Unlikely Foray Into England’s Soccer Scene
description: The province is sponsoring an obscure professional team in an effort to attract skilled immigrants.
content: This week, my colleague Rory Smith used his soccer expertise to look at the sport’s contribution to fashion. Specifically, he reported that vintage soccer jerseys have become popular street wear and that buying and selling them has turned into a major business.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Fix Social Security to Protect the Young and Old
description: Readers discuss a guest essay arguing that young people are unfairly burdened by supporting boomers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Katie Couric Spends Her Sundays
description: When Ms. Couric, the veteran journalist, is at her home in East Hampton, she spends her days at the beach, playing pickleball and FaceTiming with her baby grandson.
content: Though it has been a while since Katie Couric was at the helm of a network news broadcast, she hasn’t let her career in media go stale. In fact, Ms. Couric, 67, said she had never been busier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Ilan Godfrey
title: Using Dance to Provoke, Delight and Tell South Africa’s Stories
description: Growing up in a Black township, Vusi Mdoyi found a sprinkle of joy under apartheid in a street-dancing style known as pantsula. As a choreographer, he has elevated it into high art, injected with ideas.
content: The young boy couldn’t resist the dance moves he saw being performed around him: the rapid foot taps, the ligament-spraining knee twists, the torso shimmies, all coming together in what some might describe as a sort of urban tap dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina, Isabella Kwai, Emmett Lindner and Mark Barrett
title: ‘This Is a Disaster’: Western North Carolina Reels From Helene
description: Hundreds of roads were blocked across the region, which includes Asheville. Officials warned of more mudslides and damage to come.
content: Abandoned vehicles caked with mud. Mountainous rural roads and slices of highways washed away into rivers. Parking lots filled with people desperately searching for cellphone service, trying to tell relatives and friends they are OK — or wanting to find out who is not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: As Hezbollah Pursued a Limited War, Israel Went for a Knockout
description: The militia group seemed content to trade blows with Israel while avoiding a major conflict. A strike that killed its leader proves it miscalculated.
content: Weeks after Hamas launched the surprise attack on Israel that started the Gaza war last October, Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, laid out his group’s approach to the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: At Capacity
description: If we can’t remember the things we read and watch and even loved, do they still “count”?
content: Everyone I know seems to be talking about their memory lately, how it isn’t what it used to be. Mine isn’t, and there’s some comfort in commiseration. Yes, we’re getting older, isn’t it something to observe, how we can no longer so easily recall names or events or what it was we were just about to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Eliza Shapiro and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Humble Roots Helped Make Him Mayor. A Love of Luxury May Bring Him Down.
description: Mayor Eric Adams was elected partly on the strength of his origin story, a narrative that shrouded questions of his character, judgment and associates.
content: In December 2021, just weeks after he was elected as the second Black mayor in New York City’s history, Eric Adams took a surprise trip to Ghana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Ina Garten’s Memoir of Fortune, Work and Being Obsessed With Her Husband
description: In “Be Ready When the Luck Happens,” the TV cooking icon asks, “How easy is that?” The answer? Not very.
content: Many books open with epigraphs. Maybe Plato, the Bible or Oscar Wilde; usually lofty, and generally by a long-dead stranger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby
title: Here Is Who Remains in Hezbollah’s Leadership
description: Israel has recently killed several commanders of the Lebanese militia, including its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
content: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia, has sustained blow after blow over the past few weeks, as Israeli strikes killed several of the group’s longtime military and political leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Susanne Craig
title: Trump Gave Them a Second Chance. They Could Not Stay Out of Trouble.
description: A California woman facing trial on fraud charges is one of six people who received clemency during the Trump administration only to be accused of another crime.
content: In December 2019, Adriana Camberos began serving a 26-month sentence in federal prison for her role in a scheme to sell millions of counterfeit bottles of the caffeinated drink 5-hour Energy that had been filled with a fake concoction and sold to unsuspecting consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’: Here’s What Critics Thought of the First Episode
description: The late-night institution begins its 50th season on Saturday. Here’s how The New York Times and others covered its debut in 1975.
content: It is strange to read the early press coverage of “Saturday Night Live.” No matter how much the show has changed over the years, the focus of the criticism is still much the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 5 Podcasts for Word Nerds
description: These shows explore the origin stories of common phrases and terms, the evolution of language and the biases that affect our perceptions of speech.
content: Linguistics might sound like a dry subject, exciting only to an academically devoted few, but the rising popularity of online word games suggests otherwise. Since it’s not particularly easy to play Wordle while doing chores, these five podcasts offer an alternative way to indulge your love of language. They explore the origin stories of common phrases and terms, the shifts over time and the biases that affect how we perceive speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Ayes Have It
description: Joe Deeney’s puzzle passes unanimously.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Mozley
title: Race, Class, Land and a Teenage Love Triangle
description: In Louise Erdrich’s new novel, “The Mighty Red,” a high school jock proposes to the Ojibwe daughter of a woman who works for his family’s sugar farm.
content: On its surface, “The Mighty Red,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Louise Erdrich, is a love story turned on its head. It begins not with a tentative meeting but with a diamond ring. Eighteen-year-old Gary Geist plans on marrying his high school girlfriend, Kismet Poe, so travels from his farm in the Red River Valley to a jeweler’s store in Fargo, N.D., to pick out a “wearable fleck of eternity.” He is a jock; she is bookish. His mother, Winnie, is ecstatic about the union; hers, Crystal, distraught. After three proposals, the girl caves, and the Geists organize a wedding. Alas, the bride is sleeping with her friend Hugo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
title: Harris and Trump Are Neck and Neck in Michigan and Wisconsin, Polls Find
description: The race between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump has tightened in two of the Northern battlegrounds, New York Times/Siena College polls found.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By B.D. McClay
title: Sally Rooney Deserves Better Than This
description: To truly appreciate her novels, we have to stop imagining that they’re all about her, or about us.
content: Sally Rooney is not an interesting person. She’ll tell you this herself — recently, in an interview with The New York Times for her new novel, “Intermezzo,” she replied to a question about her hobbies with: “What do I like to do? I feel like I’m so uninteresting.” In another interview, with The Guardian, she expressed the wish not to be “the focal point” for conversation about the role of “young women in our culture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Steve Lohr
title: Killing of Nasrallah Pushes Mideast Conflict Into New Territory
description: His death is a blow to Hezbollah, the militia force and Iranian proxy he led. Whether it will cripple the group, or fuel another cycle of retribution, remains to be seen.
content: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia, on Saturday confirmed the death of Hassan Nasrallah, its longtime leader, in a strike marking a major escalation of Israel’s campaign against Iran’s proxies in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: After Your Death, Who Takes Care of the Dog?
description: A pet trust designates a new guardian for companion animals and sets aside funds for their care. Better yet, it’s legally binding.
content: In 2016, Tracy Jennings received shocking news: A lifelong friend, a woman who had a farm with animals great and small, had died suddenly in an accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Tracked Nasrallah for Months Before Assassination, Officials Say
description: The Israeli military decided to strike at the Hezbollah leader because it believed there was only a short window before he disappeared to a different location, three senior Israeli officials said.
content: Israeli leaders had been aware of Hassan Nasrallah’s whereabouts for months and decided to strike him this past week because they believed they had only a short window of opportunity before the Hezbollah leader would disappear to a different location, according to three senior Israeli defense officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Michel
title: The Indictment of Eric Adams Shouldn’t Surprise Us
description: Eric Adams is accused of injecting foreign funds directly into his election campaigns, compromising not only the mayor’s office but also American elections.
content: The new, unsealed indictment against Eric Adams, accusing him of a range of crimes over nearly a decade, is significant for any number of reasons: Mr. Adams is the first mayor in New York history to face federal indictment while in office and also, to my knowledge, the first sitting mayor in American history  indicted on charges of acting at the behest not of his constituents but of a foreign power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: No Turkish Delight for New York’s Mayor
description: The latest worm in the Big Apple.
content: It was one of the most anthropologically fascinating dinner parties I ever attended. Cindy Adams, the New York Post gossip G.O.A.T., feted her 94th birthday at her rococo Park Avenue apartment in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: Trump Voters Drive a Rise in Ticket Splitting
description: Ticket splitters in key presidential battlegrounds and Ohio tend to be supporters of Donald J. Trump who are skeptical of his picks for Senate, polling shows.
content: In the 2022 midterm elections, former President Donald J. Trump endorsed dozens of candidates down the ballot, positioning himself as Republicans’ undisputed kingmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: White Sox Lose 121 Games in a Season, Making History
description: In its weird, shambolic spectacle, the record-setting game seemed to encapsulate the team’s entire dreadful season.
content: Friday night in Detroit, as people bought hats and ate hot dogs and sang along to rock anthems, the Chicago White Sox pulled off a staggering feat. They lost their 121st game of the season, vaulting themselves into modern baseball history by breaking the record for most losses, one previously held by the 1962 Mets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: The Not-So-Brief History of Scandal Among New York City Mayors
description: Mayor Eric Adams is the first modern-era New York City mayor to be indicted. But A. Oakey Hall, his little-known predecessor, faced criminal charges 150 years earlier.
content: As federal agents conducted an early-morning search of Gracie Mansion on Thursday, the name “Elegant Oakey” was probably not foremost in their minds. It sounds like a hot tip running the third race at Aqueduct Racetrack, or a retro speakeasy feigning authenticity on the Lower East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: The Fans Want to Watch Football. Trump and Walz Will Be There, Too.
description: Donald Trump and Tim Walz are attending college games on Saturday that will draw plenty of viewers in the swing states of Michigan and Georgia.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Bombs Residential Site in Effort to Kill Hezbollah Leader
description: The strike came barely an hour after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, delivered a fiery address to the U.N. General Assembly.
content: The Israeli military bombed residential buildings south of Beirut on Friday that it said stood over the central headquarters of Hezbollah, barely an hour after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delivered a combative address to the United Nations in which he vowed to defeat the group and other Iranian-backed militias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk and Chris Cameron
title: JD Vance Faces Scrutiny Over Past Criticisms of Trump and Car Seats
description: The Republican vice-presidential nominee reportedly said that Donald J. Trump “failed to deliver” on economic populism and tied car-seat regulations to fewer births.
content: As Senator JD Vance of Ohio prepares for the vice-presidential debate next week, several past statements — including a private message in which he reportedly criticized former President Donald J. Trump near the end of his term and a video of him linking car-seat regulations to low birthrates — came back to haunt him on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Singer
title: The Surprising Place Analysts Look to for Election Forecasting
description: Washington State’s primaries have a record of predicting the national mood, making it a bellwether of sorts.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When to Vote in Your State
description: See the important deadlines for registering to vote, mailing ballots and voting early in person.

author: By Matthew Cassel and Chevaz Clarke
title: Shock and Uncertainty in Beirut After Nasrallah’s Death
description: Israel’s killing of Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was a stunning escalation of the country’s campaign against the Iran-backed group.
content: Israel’s killing of Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was a stunning escalation of the country’s campaign against the Iran-backed group.

author: By Matthew Cassel and Meg Felling
title: ‘We’re Still Living in Fear’: Escaping the Attacks in Lebanon
description: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Lebanon. Khaled Hussein, 20, fled Syria as a child. He describes the bombardment that forced his family to flee again.
content: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Lebanon. Khaled Hussein, 20, fled Syria as a child. He describes the bombardment that forced his family to flee again.

author: By Judson Jones, Karen Hanley, Claire Hogan, Alexandra Ostasiewicz and James Surdam
title: Why Hurricane Helene Was So Strong
description: In just over 12 hours, Hurricane Helene transformed from a Category 1 to a Category 4 hurricane — the strongest ever to hit the Big Bend coast of Florida. Judson Jones, a meteorologist and reporter for The New York Times covering extreme weather, explains why it grew so strong.
content: In just over 12 hours, Hurricane Helene transformed from a Category 1 to a Category 4 hurricane — the strongest ever to hit the Big Bend coast of Florida. Judson Jones, a meteorologist and reporter for The New York Times covering extreme weather, explains why it grew so strong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Claire Hogan and Gabriel Blanco
title: Who Was Hassan Nasrallah, Leader of Hezbollah?
description: The leader of the militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by an Israeli airstrike in Lebanon on Friday. Neil MacFarquhar, a reporter for The New York Times who met and interviewed Nasrallah in 2002, explains who he was and the significance of his death.
content: The leader of the militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by an Israeli airstrike in Lebanon on Friday. Neil MacFarquhar, a reporter for The New York Times who met and interviewed Nasrallah in 2002, explains who he was and the significance of his death.

title: How to Understand Election Polls

title: ‘The Interview’: John Oliver Is Still Working Through the Rage
description: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.
content: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.
